news_summary: Advancements in AI and quantum computing are driving breakthroughs in sustainable materials, problem-solving capabilities, and improved network reliability.
news_summary_fr: Les progrès de l'IA et de l'informatique quantique sont à l'origine de percées dans le domaine des matériaux durables, des capacités de résolution de problèmes et de l'amélioration de la fiabilité des réseaux.
news_summary_es: Los avances en IA y computación cuántica están impulsando grandes progresos en materiales sostenibles, capacidad de resolución de problemas y mejora de la fiabilidad de las redes.

articles.title: Concrete that lasts centuries and captures carbon? AI just made it possible
articles.summary: Imagine concrete that not only survives wildfires and extreme weather, but heals itself and absorbs carbon from the air. Scientists at USC have created an AI model called Allegro-FM that simulates billions of atoms at once, helping design futuristic materials like carbon-neutral concrete. This tech could transform cities by reducing emissions, extending building lifespans, and mimicking the ancient durability of Roman concrete—all thanks to a massive leap in AI-driven atomic modeling.
articles.content:
Imagine the concrete in our homes and bridges not only withstanding the ravages of time and natural disasters like the intense heat of wildfires, but actively self-healing or capturing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.

Now, researchers at the USC Viterbi School of Engineering have developed a revolutionary AI model that can simulate the behavior of billions of atoms simultaneously, opening new possibilities for materials design and discovery at unprecedented scales.

The current state of the world's climate is a dire one. Brutal droughts, evaporating glaciers, and more disastrous hurricanes, rainstorms and wildfires devastate us each year. A major contributor to global warming is the constant emission of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.

Aiichiro Nakano, a USC Viterbi professor of computer science, physics and astronomy, and quantitative and computational biology, was contemplating these issues after the January wildfires in Los Angeles. So, he reached out to longtime partner Ken-Ichi Nomura, a USC Viterbi professor of chemical engineering and materials science practice, with whom he's collaborated for over 20 years.

Discussing these issues together helped spark their new project: Allegro-FM, an artificial intelligence-driven simulation model. Allegro-FM has made a startling theoretical discovery: it is possible to recapture carbon dioxide emitted in the process of making concrete and place it back into the concrete that it helped produce.

"You can just put the CO2 inside the concrete, and then that makes a carbon-neutral concrete," Nakano said.

Nakano and Nomura, along with Priya Vashishta, a USC Viterbi professor of chemical engineering and materials science, and Rajiv Kalia, a USC professor of physics and astronomy, have been doing research on what they call "CO2 sequestration," or the process of recapturing carbon dioxide and storing it, a challenging process.

By simulating billions of atoms simultaneously, Allegro-FM can test different concrete chemistries virtually before expensive real-world experiments. This could accelerate the development of concrete that acts as a carbon sink rather than just a carbon source -- concrete production currently accounts for about 8% of global CO2 emissions.

The breakthrough lies in the model's scalability. While existing molecular simulation methods are limited to systems with thousands or millions of atoms, Allegro-FM demonstrated 97.5% efficiency when simulating over four billion atoms on the Aurora supercomputer at Argonne National Laboratory.

This represents computational capabilities roughly 1,000 times larger than conventional approaches.

The model also covers 89 chemical elements and can predict molecular behavior for applications ranging from cement chemistry to carbon storage.

"Concrete is also a very complex material. It consists of many elements and different phases and interfaces. So, traditionally, we didn't have a way to simulate phenomena involving concrete material. But now we can use this Allegro-FM to simulate mechanical properties [and] structural properties," Nomura said.

Concrete is a fire-resistant material, making it an ideal building choice in the wake of the January wildfires. But concrete production is also a huge emitter of carbon dioxide, a particularly concerning environmental problem in a city like Los Angeles. In their simulations, Allegro-FM has been shown to be carbon neutral, making it a better choice than other concrete.

This breakthrough doesn't only solve one problem. Modern concrete only lasts about 100 years on average, whereas ancient Roman concrete has lasted for over 2,000 years. But the recapture of CO2 can help this as well.

"If you put in the CO2, the so-called 'carbonate layer,' it becomes more robust," Nakano said.

In other words, Allegro-FM can simulate a carbon-neutral concrete that could also last much longer than the 100 years concrete typically lasts nowadays. Now it's just a matter of building it.

Behind the scenes

The professors led the development of Allegro-FM with an appreciation for how AI has been an accelerator of their complex work. Normally, to simulate the behavior of atoms, the professors would need a precise series of mathematical formulas -- or, as Nomura called them, "profound, deep quantum mechanics phenomena."

But the last two years have changed the way the two research.

"Now, because of this machine-learning AI breakthrough, instead of deriving all these quantum mechanics from scratch, researchers are taking [the] approach of generating a training set and then letting the machine learning model run," Nomura said. This makes the professors' process much faster as well as more efficient in its technology use.

Allegro-FM can accurately predict "interaction functions" between atoms -- in other words, how atoms react and interact with each other. Normally, these interaction functions would require lots of individual simulations.

But this new model changes that. Originally, there were different equations for individual elements within the periodic table, with several unique functions for these elements. With the help of AI and machine-learning, though, we can now potentially simulate these interaction functions with nearly the entire periodic table at the same time, without the requirement for separate formulas.

"The traditional approach is to simulate a certain set of materials. So, you can simulate, let's say, silica glass, but you cannot simulate [that] with, let's say, a drug molecule," Nomura said.

This new system is also a lot more efficient on the technology side, with AI models making lots of precise calculations that used to be done by a large supercomputer, simplifying tasks and freeing up that supercomputer's resources for more advanced research.

"[The AI can] achieve quantum mechanical accuracy with much, much smaller computing resources," Nakano said.

Nomura and Nakano say their work is far from over.

"We will certainly continue this concrete study research, making more complex geometries and surfaces," Nomura said.

This research was published recently in The Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters and was featured as the journal's cover image.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a significant scientific and technological breakthrough using AI to create durable, self-healing, and carbon-absorbing concrete. This innovation has strong environmental benefits by reducing emissions and extending building lifespans, offering hope for sustainable urban development and climate change mitigation.
articles.personality_title: Concrete that heals itself and fights climate change, thanks to AI
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Concrete is everywhere—from our homes to bridges—but it usually wears down over time, especially when faced with harsh weather or fires. Scientists have long dreamed of making concrete that lasts longer, repairs itself, and even helps the environment.

**What happened**
Researchers at the University of Southern California created an AI model called Allegro-FM that can simulate billions of atoms at once. This powerful tool helps design new materials, including a special kind of concrete that can heal cracks and absorb carbon dioxide from the air.

**Impact**
This breakthrough means future buildings could be stronger, safer, and better for the planet. By capturing carbon, the concrete helps reduce greenhouse gases, while its self-healing ability extends the life of structures, cutting down on waste and repair costs.

**What's next step**
The team plans to refine this AI model further and test the new concrete in real-world conditions. This will help ensure it performs well and can be used widely in cities around the world.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Thanks to AI, we’re closer than ever to concrete that not only lasts for centuries but also helps fight climate change by healing itself and capturing carbon.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un béton qui se répare et combat le changement climatique, grâce à l’IA
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le béton est partout—dans nos maisons et nos ponts—mais il s’use avec le temps, surtout face aux intempéries ou aux incendies. Les scientifiques rêvent depuis longtemps d’un béton plus durable, capable de s’auto-réparer et même de protéger l’environnement.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des chercheurs de l’Université de Californie du Sud ont créé un modèle d’IA appelé Allegro-FM qui peut simuler des milliards d’atomes en même temps. Cet outil puissant aide à concevoir de nouveaux matériaux, dont un béton spécial qui répare ses fissures et absorbe le dioxyde de carbone de l’air.

**Impact**
Cette avancée signifie que les futurs bâtiments pourraient être plus solides, plus sûrs et meilleurs pour la planète. En capturant le carbone, le béton aide à réduire les gaz à effet de serre, tandis que sa capacité d’auto-réparation prolonge la durée de vie des structures, réduisant déchets et coûts de réparation.

**Prochaine étape**
L’équipe prévoit de perfectionner ce modèle d’IA et de tester ce nouveau béton en conditions réelles. Cela garantira sa performance et son usage à grande échelle dans les villes du monde entier.

**Message clé en une phrase**
Grâce à l’IA, nous sommes plus proches que jamais d’un béton qui dure des siècles et aide à lutter contre le changement climatique en se réparant et en capturant le carbone.
articles.personality_title_es: Hormigón que se repara y combate el cambio climático, gracias a la IA
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El hormigón está en todas partes—en nuestras casas y puentes—pero se desgasta con el tiempo, especialmente frente a condiciones climáticas extremas o incendios. Los científicos han soñado durante mucho tiempo con un hormigón que dure más, se repare solo y ayude al medio ambiente.

**Qué pasó**
Investigadores de la Universidad del Sur de California crearon un modelo de IA llamado Allegro-FM que puede simular miles de millones de átomos a la vez. Esta herramienta poderosa ayuda a diseñar nuevos materiales, incluido un tipo especial de hormigón que puede reparar grietas y absorber dióxido de carbono del aire.

**Impacto**
Este avance significa que los edificios del futuro podrían ser más fuertes, seguros y mejores para el planeta. Al capturar carbono, el hormigón ayuda a reducir los gases de efecto invernadero, y su capacidad de autocuración extiende la vida útil de las estructuras, reduciendo residuos y costos de reparación.

**Próximo paso**
El equipo planea perfeccionar este modelo de IA y probar el nuevo hormigón en condiciones reales. Esto ayudará a asegurar que funcione bien y pueda usarse ampliamente en ciudades de todo el mundo.

**Frase clave**
Gracias a la IA, estamos más cerca que nunca de un hormigón que no solo dura siglos sino que también ayuda a combatir el cambio climático reparándose y capturando carbono.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of a glowing, ancient Roman-style concrete pillar embedded with vibrant, swirling atomic patterns symbolizing billions of atoms, surrounded by gentle, translucent wisps of captured carbon dioxide gently flowing into and strengthening the pillar, set against a calm, abstract background evoking both resilience and advanced scientific discovery.

articles.title: One small qubit, one giant leap for quantum computing
articles.summary: Aalto University physicists in Finland have set a new benchmark in quantum computing by achieving a record-breaking millisecond coherence in a transmon qubit — nearly doubling prior limits. This development not only opens the door to far more powerful and stable quantum computations but also reduces the burden of error correction.
articles.content:
On July 8, 2025, physicists from Aalto University in Finland published a transmon qubit coherence dramatically surpassing previous scientifically published records. The millisecond coherence measurement marks a quantum leap in computational technology, with the previous maximum echo coherence measurements approaching 0.6 milliseconds.

Longer qubit coherence allows for an extended window of time in which quantum computers can execute error-free operations, enabling more complex quantum computations and more quantum logic operations before errors occur. Not only does this allow for more calculations with noisy quantum computers, but it also decreases the resources needed for quantum error correction, which is a path to noiseless quantum computing.

"We have just measured an echo coherence time for a transmon qubit that landed at a millisecond at maximum with a median of half a millisecond," says Mikko Tuokkola, the PhD student who conducted and analyzed the measurements. The median reading is particularly significant, as it also surpasses current recorded readings.

The findings have been just published in the prestigious peer-reviewed journal Nature Communications.

The researchers report their approach as thoroughly as possible, with the aim of making it reproducible for research groups around the world.

Finland cements position at forefront of quantum

Tuokkala was supervised at Aalto University by postdoctoral researcher Dr. Yoshiki Sunada, who fabricated the chip and built the measurement setup.

"We have been able to reproducibly fabricate high-quality transmon qubits. The fact that this can be achieved in a cleanroom which is accessible for academic research is a testament to Finland's leading position in quantum science and technology," adds Sunada who is currently working in Stanford University, USA.

The work is a result of the Quantum Computing and Devices (QCD) research group which is a part of Aalto University's Department of Applied Physics, Academy of Finland Centre of Excellence in Quantum Technology (QTF), and the Finnish Quantum Flagship (FQF).

The qubit was fabricated by the QCD group at Aalto using high-quality superconducting film supplied by the Technical Research Centre of Finland (VTT). The success reflects the high quality of Micronova cleanrooms at OtaNano, Finland's national research infrastructure for micro-, nano-, and quantum technologies.

"This landmark achievement has strengthened Finland's standing as a global leader in the field, moving the needle forward on what can be made possible with the quantum computers of the future," says Professor of Quantum Technology Mikko Möttönen, who heads the QCD group.

Scaling up the quantum computers of the future requires advancements across several domains. Among them are noise reduction, qubit-count increases, and the qubit coherence time improvements at the center of the new observations from the QCD. The group just opened a senior staff member and two postdocs positions for achieving future breakthroughs faster.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in quantum computing that promises more powerful and stable computations, potentially impacting many technological fields positively. This kind of advancement is generally seen as hopeful and inspiring for the future of technology and innovation.
articles.personality_title: One small qubit, one giant leap for quantum computing
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Quantum computers hold the promise of solving complex problems far beyond the reach of today’s machines. At the heart of these computers are qubits, tiny units that store and process information. How long a qubit can stay stable, or coherent, is crucial for reliable calculations.

**What happened**
Physicists at Aalto University in Finland have achieved a remarkable breakthrough by creating a transmon qubit that stays coherent for a whole millisecond. This nearly doubles the previous record of about 0.6 milliseconds. Longer coherence means the qubit can perform more operations without errors.

**Impact**
This discovery is a major step forward for quantum computing. With longer coherence times, quantum computers can run more complex tasks and make fewer errors. It also means less need for complicated error correction, which makes building practical quantum machines easier and more efficient.

**What's next step**
Researchers will now focus on integrating these longer-lasting qubits into larger quantum systems. They will also work on improving other aspects of qubit performance to build more powerful and reliable quantum computers that can tackle real-world problems.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Aalto University’s new qubit coherence record brings us closer to practical and powerful quantum computers that could transform technology as we know it.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un petit qubit, un grand bond pour l'informatique quantique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les ordinateurs quantiques promettent de résoudre des problèmes complexes bien au-delà des capacités des ordinateurs actuels. Au cœur de ces machines se trouvent les qubits, de petites unités qui stockent et traitent l'information. La durée pendant laquelle un qubit reste stable, ou cohérent, est essentielle pour des calculs fiables.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Des physiciens de l'université Aalto en Finlande ont réalisé une avancée remarquable en créant un qubit transmon qui reste cohérent pendant une milliseconde entière. Cela double presque le record précédent d'environ 0,6 milliseconde. Une cohérence plus longue signifie que le qubit peut effectuer plus d'opérations sans erreurs.

**Impact**
Cette découverte est une avancée majeure pour l'informatique quantique. Avec des temps de cohérence plus longs, les ordinateurs quantiques peuvent exécuter des tâches plus complexes et faire moins d'erreurs. Cela réduit aussi le besoin de corrections d'erreurs compliquées, ce qui facilite et rend plus efficace la construction de machines quantiques pratiques.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs vont maintenant se concentrer sur l'intégration de ces qubits à longue durée dans des systèmes quantiques plus grands. Ils travailleront aussi à améliorer d'autres aspects des performances des qubits pour construire des ordinateurs quantiques plus puissants et fiables capables de résoudre des problèmes concrets.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
Le nouveau record de cohérence des qubits de l'université Aalto nous rapproche d'ordinateurs quantiques pratiques et puissants qui pourraient transformer la technologie telle que nous la connaissons.
articles.personality_title_es: Un pequeño qubit, un gran salto para la computación cuántica
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Las computadoras cuánticas prometen resolver problemas complejos mucho más allá del alcance de las máquinas actuales. En el centro de estas computadoras están los qubits, pequeñas unidades que almacenan y procesan información. El tiempo que un qubit puede mantenerse estable, o coherente, es clave para cálculos confiables.

**Qué pasó**
Físicos de la Universidad Aalto en Finlandia lograron un avance impresionante al crear un qubit transmon que permanece coherente durante un milisegundo completo. Esto casi duplica el récord previo de alrededor de 0.6 milisegundos. Una coherencia más larga significa que el qubit puede realizar más operaciones sin errores.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento es un gran paso para la computación cuántica. Con tiempos de coherencia más largos, las computadoras cuánticas pueden ejecutar tareas más complejas y cometer menos errores. También reduce la necesidad de correcciones de errores complicadas, haciendo más fácil y eficiente construir máquinas cuánticas prácticas.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores ahora se enfocarán en integrar estos qubits de larga duración en sistemas cuánticos más grandes. También trabajarán para mejorar otros aspectos del rendimiento de los qubits para construir computadoras cuánticas más potentes y confiables que puedan resolver problemas reales.

**Conclusión en una frase**
El nuevo récord de coherencia de qubits de la Universidad Aalto nos acerca a computadoras cuánticas prácticas y potentes que podrían transformar la tecnología tal como la conocemos.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a glowing, intricately designed superconducting quantum chip resting on a softly illuminated laboratory table, surrounded by abstract waves of light representing extended qubit coherence, with subtle northern lights in the background symbolizing Finland’s leading role in quantum technology, all rendered in gentle, natural hues of blue, silver, and soft green.

articles.title: DeepMind and OpenAI models solve maths problems at level of top students
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 24 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02343-xFor the first time, large language models performed on a par with gold medallists in the International Mathematical Olympiad.
articles.content:
Models from OpenAI and DeepMind achieved gold medal scores in the International Mathematical Olympiad.Credit: MoiraM/Alamy

Google DeepMind announced on 21 July that its software had cracked a set of maths problems at the level of the world’s top high-school students, achieving a gold-medal score on questions from the International Mathematical Olympiad. At first sight, this marked only a marginal improvement over the prevous year’s performance. The company’s system had performed in the upper range of silver medal standard at the 2024 Olympiad, while this year it was evaluated in the lower range for a human gold medallist.

DeepMind AI crushes tough maths problems on par with top human solvers

But the grades this year hide a “big paradigm shift,” says Thang Luong, a computer scientist at DeepMind in Mountain View, California. The company achieved its previous feats using two artificial intelligence (AI) tools specifically designed to carry out rigorous logical steps in mathematical proofscalculations, called AlphaGeometry and AlphaProof. The process required human experts to first translate the problems’ statements into something similar to a programming language, and then to translate the AI’s solutions back into English.

“This year, everything is natural language, end to end,” says Luong. The team employed a large language model (LLM) called DeepThink, which is based on its Gemini system but with some additional developments that made it better and faster at producing mathematical arguments, such as handling multiple chains of thought in parallel. “For a long time, I didn’t think we could go that far with LLMs,” Luong adds.

DeepThink scored 35 out of 42 points on the 6 problems that had been given to participants in this year’s Olympiad. Under an agreement with the organizers, the computer’s solutions were marked by the same judges who evaluated the human participants.

Separately, ChatGPT creator OpenAI, based in San Francisco, California, had its own LLM solve the same Mathematical Olympiad problems at gold medal level, but had its solutions evaluated independently.

Impressive performance

For years, many AI researchers have fallen in one of two camps. Until 2012, the leading approach for was to code the rules of logical thinking into the machine by hand. Since then, neural networks — which train automatically by learning from vast troves of data — have made a series of sensational breakthroughs, and tools such as OpenAI’s ChatGPT have now entered mainstream use.

DeepMind AI solves geometry problems at star-student level

Gary Marcus, a neuroscientist at New York University (NYU) in New York City, called the results by DeepMind and OpenAI “Awfully impressive.” Marcus is an advocate of the ‘coding logic by hand’ approach — also known as neurosymbolic AI — and a frequent critic of what he sees as hype surrounding LLMs. Still, writing on Substack with NYU computer scientist Ernest Davis, he commented that “to be able to solve math problems at the level of the top 67 high school students in the world is to have really good math problem solving chops”.

It remains to be seen whether LLM superiority on IMO problems is here to stay, or if neurosymbolic AI will claw its way back to the top. “At this point the two camps still keep developing,” says Luong, who works on both approaches. “They could converge together.”
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a significant technological and educational achievement where AI models have matched the performance of top human students in complex mathematics competitions, showcasing progress in AI capabilities and potential benefits for education and problem-solving.
articles.personality_title: AI models solve top-level math problems like gold medalists
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
The International Mathematical Olympiad is a tough competition where the best high-school students from around the world solve challenging math problems. Scoring a gold medal here means you’re among the smartest young mathematicians globally.

**What happened**
DeepMind and OpenAI, two leading AI companies, created large language models that have now solved math problems at the same level as gold medal winners in this Olympiad. This means their AI can think through complex math questions just like top human students.

**Impact**
This achievement shows AI is getting better at understanding and solving difficult problems, not just simple calculations. It opens doors for using AI to help students learn and for researchers to tackle complex challenges faster.

**What's next step**
The next goal is to improve these AI systems so they can explain their reasoning clearly and help teach math in classrooms. Making AI a supportive learning tool could boost education worldwide.

**One-sentence takeaway**
AI has reached a new milestone by matching the math skills of the world’s best high-school students, promising exciting advances in education and problem-solving.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des modèles d'IA résolvent des problèmes mathématiques de niveau médaillé d'or
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
L'Olympiade internationale de mathématiques est une compétition difficile où les meilleurs lycéens du monde entier résolvent des problèmes de mathématiques complexes. Obtenir une médaille d'or signifie faire partie des jeunes mathématiciens les plus brillants au monde.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
DeepMind et OpenAI, deux grandes entreprises d'IA, ont créé des modèles de langage capables désormais de résoudre des problèmes mathématiques au même niveau que les médaillés d'or de cette Olympiade. Leur IA peut donc réfléchir à des questions mathématiques complexes comme les meilleurs élèves.

**Impact**
Cette réussite montre que l'IA progresse pour comprendre et résoudre des problèmes difficiles, pas seulement des calculs simples. Cela ouvre la voie à l'utilisation de l'IA pour aider les élèves à apprendre et pour aider les chercheurs à relever des défis complexes plus rapidement.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
L'objectif est maintenant d'améliorer ces systèmes d'IA pour qu'ils expliquent clairement leur raisonnement et aident à enseigner les mathématiques en classe. Faire de l'IA un outil d'apprentissage pourrait booster l'éducation dans le monde.

**Une phrase à retenir**
L'IA a atteint un nouveau cap en égalant les compétences mathématiques des meilleurs lycéens du monde, promettant des avancées passionnantes en éducation et en résolution de problèmes.
articles.personality_title_es: Modelos de IA resuelven problemas matemáticos de nivel medallista de oro
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
La Olimpiada Internacional de Matemáticas es una competencia difícil donde los mejores estudiantes de secundaria del mundo resuelven problemas matemáticos complejos. Obtener una medalla de oro significa ser uno de los jóvenes matemáticos más brillantes del mundo.

**Qué pasó**
DeepMind y OpenAI, dos importantes empresas de IA, crearon modelos de lenguaje grandes que ahora resuelven problemas matemáticos al mismo nivel que los ganadores de medallas de oro en esta Olimpiada. Esto significa que su IA puede pensar en preguntas matemáticas complejas igual que los mejores estudiantes humanos.

**Impacto**
Este logro muestra que la IA está mejorando para entender y resolver problemas difíciles, no solo cálculos simples. Abre puertas para usar IA para ayudar a los estudiantes a aprender y para que los investigadores aborden desafíos complejos más rápido.

**Próximo paso**
El siguiente objetivo es mejorar estos sistemas de IA para que expliquen su razonamiento claramente y ayuden a enseñar matemáticas en las aulas. Convertir la IA en una herramienta de apoyo al aprendizaje podría impulsar la educación en todo el mundo.

**Conclusión en una frase**
La IA ha alcanzado un nuevo hito al igualar las habilidades matemáticas de los mejores estudiantes de secundaria del mundo, prometiendo avances emocionantes en educación y resolución de problemas.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of an elegant, glowing golden medal resting atop an open ancient mathematical manuscript filled with intricate geometric diagrams and handwritten formulas, surrounded by softly illuminated, flowing strands of light symbolizing interconnected chains of thought and artificial intelligence, all rendered in gentle natural earth tones and soft blues.

articles.title: EE and BT network outage resolved, firm says
articles.summary: The government says "EE and BT digital voice calls to 999 have now been restored."
articles.content:
EE and BT network outage resolved, firm says

8 hours ago Share Save Imran Rahman-Jones Technology reporter Share Save

Getty Images

A network outage affecting thousands of EE and BT customers has been resolved, a spokesperson has said. Customers reported they were unable to make or receive calls as the mobile phone and landline networks faced an outage. Some customers reported issues with making 999 calls, but the government said these had "now been restored". A spokesperson from BT, which owns EE, apologised for the outage and said it has "resolved the problem and the service is running as normal".

The spokesperson said late on Thursday the issue happened "following a technical fault impacting voice services on our network earlier today". Outages tracker Downdetector, which relies on self-reported user data, showed over 2,500 EE customers experiencing outages at 14:00 BST, with many also reporting issues with other networks. Vodafone and Three confirmed to the BBC that they did not have network issues. Other networks had seen spikes in reports of outages on Downdetector - but these were likely to be customers from networks unable to connect to EE or BT phone numbers. Social media users had been posting about a loss of services of both EE and BT mobile and landline services.

999 calls

BT said customers should use 999 as normal. However, on Thursday afternoon, Devon and Somerset Fire and Rescue Services posted on social media to say there was "a fault with the mobile phone network, including 999 calls". But they posted an update at 15:01 BST on X to say 999 calls had returned to normal. South Western Ambulance Service then posted on X to confirm there was an issue. The Department of Science, Innovation and Technology said the outage had "impacted some customers' ability to make and receive calls between EE and other networks. "EE and BT digital voice calls to 999 have now been restored." A spokesperson added: "Communications providers have statutory obligations to ensure their networks and services are appropriately resilient."

Customer impact
articles.reasoning: The resolution of a major network outage restoring emergency call services is positive news as it ensures public safety and the reliability of critical communication infrastructure.
articles.personality_title: EE and BT fix network outage, emergency calls restored
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Thousands of people using EE and BT faced trouble making and receiving calls because their phone networks went down. This included problems reaching emergency services, which caused concern across the UK.

**What happened**
The companies quickly worked to fix the issue. After several hours, the network outage ended, and normal phone service was back. The government confirmed that calls to 999 emergency services were once again working properly.

**Impact**
Restoring phone services, especially emergency calls, was vital for public safety. People can now trust that their phone lines will connect when it matters most, preventing panic and ensuring help is reachable.

**What's next step**
EE and BT will review what caused the outage to prevent future problems. They will likely improve their systems and communication so customers stay informed if issues happen again.

**One-sentence takeaway**
The quick fix of EE and BT’s network outage brought back reliable phone and emergency call services, keeping people safe and connected.
articles.personality_title_fr: EE et BT réparent la panne réseau, les appels d'urgence rétablis
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Des milliers de personnes utilisant EE et BT ont eu du mal à passer et recevoir des appels car leurs réseaux téléphoniques sont tombés en panne. Cela incluait des problèmes pour joindre les services d'urgence, ce qui a inquiété tout le Royaume-Uni.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Les entreprises ont rapidement travaillé pour résoudre le problème. Après plusieurs heures, la panne du réseau a pris fin et le service téléphonique est revenu à la normale. Le gouvernement a confirmé que les appels aux services d'urgence 999 fonctionnaient à nouveau correctement.

**Impact**
Le rétablissement des services téléphoniques, en particulier les appels d'urgence, était vital pour la sécurité publique. Les gens peuvent désormais faire confiance à leurs lignes téléphoniques pour se connecter quand cela compte le plus, évitant la panique et assurant que l'aide est accessible.

**Prochaine étape**
EE et BT vont examiner la cause de la panne pour éviter que cela se reproduise. Ils amélioreront probablement leurs systèmes et la communication pour que les clients soient informés en cas de nouveau problème.

**À retenir en une phrase**
La réparation rapide de la panne réseau d’EE et BT a rétabli des services téléphoniques fiables et les appels d’urgence, assurant la sécurité et la connexion des personnes.
articles.personality_title_es: EE y BT solucionan la caída de red, llamadas de emergencia restauradas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Miles de personas que usan EE y BT tuvieron problemas para hacer y recibir llamadas porque sus redes telefónicas fallaron. Esto incluía dificultades para llamar a los servicios de emergencia, lo que preocupó en todo el Reino Unido.

**Qué pasó**
Las compañías trabajaron rápido para arreglar el problema. Después de varias horas, se terminó la caída de la red y el servicio telefónico volvió a la normalidad. El gobierno confirmó que las llamadas al 999, servicio de emergencia, funcionaban nuevamente sin problemas.

**Impacto**
Restaurar los servicios telefónicos, especialmente las llamadas de emergencia, fue vital para la seguridad pública. La gente ahora puede confiar en que sus líneas telefónicas conectarán cuando más importa, evitando pánico y asegurando que la ayuda esté disponible.

**Próximo paso**
EE y BT revisarán qué causó la caída para evitar problemas futuros. Probablemente mejorarán sus sistemas y comunicación para mantener informados a los clientes si vuelve a ocurrir un problema.

**Mensaje en una frase**
La rápida solución de la caída de red de EE y BT restauró los servicios telefónicos y las llamadas de emergencia, manteniendo a las personas seguras y conectadas.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a glowing, sturdy telephone tower surrounded by interconnected glowing phone lines gently reconnecting across a calm cityscape at dusk, symbolizing restored communication and reliability, rendered in soft natural earth tones and blues with subtle light accents.
